The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two myxozoans, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to P. hydriforme. They also suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the origin of parasitic lifestyles. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to cause disease. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and interacts with the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is involved in the nuclear import of ISGs. We also show that a simple mutation in Orf6 abolishes its ability to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. These results unveil a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune system and may help in the development of new strategies to combat COVID-19. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use a statistical model to project the future yield variability of maize, the world’s most important cereal crop, under two levels of global warming. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off or closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is expected to vary widely, with some businesses expecting to remain open for years. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, the majority of businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global scale of the problem is still unknown. We show that the distribution of floating plastic debris in the open ocean is not as widespread as expected, and that the missing plastic is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. This distribution is the result of a combination of selective sinks and sources, which are still poorly understood. This study provides a better understanding of the distribution of floating plastic debris in the ocean, and may help to identify the most effective strategies to reduce the impact of this pollution.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in science. The solar system is thought to have formed from the aggregation of interstellar dust particles. However, the age of the solar system is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. Our results show that the solar system is not as old as previously thought.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother during pregnancy is a defining characteristic of all placental mammals. This ability is thought to be the result of domestication and allonursing. Here, we show that both of these factors increase the amount of energy available to the mother and that this increase is associated with an increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the number of offspring rather than an increase in the size of each offspring. This result suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals is metabolic power rather than resource availability.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the inflammatory protease caspase-1 is responsible for the cleavage of the C terminus of α-syn, which is then prone to aggregation. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be of great importance, as there is no treatment available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the first line of defense against pathogens and debris and is the primary regulator of blood flow and blood vessel tone. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform a variety of functions. This paper describes the structure of the endothelial network, which is the communication system between the cells. The network is a small-world network, which is a type of network that is both efficient at transmitting information and robust to the loss of connections. The network is also scale-free, which means that the number of connections between cells is not evenly distributed. This paper describes the structure of the network and how it is optimized for communication between cells. The network is a key component of the cardiovascular system and is essential for the health of the body. Understanding the structure of the network is important for improving our understanding of the cardiovascular system and for developing new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has presented enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary indicators that are not available elsewhere. These indicators are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the targets of a large number of drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the KcsA mutant channel. Finally, it provides a structural explanation for the collapse of the selectivity filter in closed-state inactivation. This work is expected to be of interest to a wide range of researchers.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in human health and disease. However, the role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is not fully understood. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system that is influenced by the host and the host environment. This study shows that anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome have the potential to synthesize natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats and that this effect is mediated by the mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. These results also suggest that the brain energy metabolism may be a target for the treatment of anxiety disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

The design of mechanical structures with programmable and extreme responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we use a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple hyperelastic materials, which seamlessly collaborate to produce the target responses. The structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin content of red blood cells is determined by the expression of two globin genes, alpha and beta, which are expressed in a developmental context-dependent manner. This study demonstrates that the IGF2BP1 protein, which binds to and stabilizes the mRNA of the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. This down-regulation of IGF2BP1 is associated with a developmental reversal of the adult hemoglobin profile toward a more fetal-like pattern. This study provides evidence for a mechanism of chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by the mTORC1-SREBP1-SCD1 pathway, which promotes lipogenesis and thus protects cancer cells from oxidative stress. This mechanism of resistance can be overcome by combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction. These findings have implications for the development of new therapies for cancer. Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate a store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is required for the development of vascular remodeling. Our findings suggest that the use of LCCBs should be limited to patients with mild hypertension. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the adverse effects of LCCBs and may lead to the development of new drugs for treating hypertension. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the policy had little effect on the conservation of older-forest–associated birds, but did reduce the decline of early-seral–associated birds. However, the policy failed to halt the decline of older forests, and the early-seral ecosystem area declined in two ecoregions. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess the performance of the design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy is expected to be a useful tool for the development of new antibiotics.

Deep learning has been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in deep networks can be very large, which can make training and applying the network difficult. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a relatively small number of parameters. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales, and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. The proposed architecture can be used in many image-processing problems. We expect that the proposed architecture will be useful in practice.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of adaptive radiation, where a single ancestral species diversified into a large number of distinct species. The ability of the species flock to rapidly adapt to changing environmental conditions is thought to be a key factor in the success of the cichlids. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the region, which shows that the Lake Malawi ecosystem was highly sensitive to changes in the climate. The record shows that the ecosystem was highly dynamic, with frequent changes in the size of the lake and the position of the shoreline. The record also shows that the climate was drier before the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), and wetter after the MPT, and that these changes were closely linked to shifts in the position of the shoreline. The rapid evolution of the cichlid species flock is thought to have been a key factor in the success of the Lake Malawi ecosystem, and our results suggest that the ability of the ecosystem to rapidly adapt to changing conditions was a key factor in the success of the cichlid species flock.

The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of these devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device before bedtime results in a delayed circadian clock, reduced melatonin, and reduced alertness the next morning. These effects are likely to have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Holocene, but the cause of this cooling is still debated. One of the proposed causes is the impact of a bolide. We show that the osmium isotope composition of the Younger Dryas sediments is consistent with the terrestrial origin of the osmium. In addition, we show that the spherules found in the same sediments are consistent with their origin from a bolide impact.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been the subject of intense investigation. However, the specific contribution of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is complex and depends on the stage of development.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles is linked to the evolution of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes, which were key to the evolution of specialized herbivory. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against variants of concern. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the size of the population did affect the variation in plane performance and the quality of the planes that participants could access. These findings are important for understanding the conditions under which larger populations enhance CCE. They also have implications for the design of cultural evolution experiments.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with a twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with a twofold decreased risk. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also suggest a hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses and enhances synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration, thereby increasing AD risk. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis. They also suggest a hypothesis for the pathogenesis of AD.

The inner core is a solid sphere that is 1,220 km in diameter and has a density of 12.04 g/cm3. It is the only solid sphere in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by the solidification of molten iron, but the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. This study shows that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more favorable than that of the hcp phase under the conditions of the inner core. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. View Full-Text

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain effects of marijuana are not well understood, the drug is known to increase the availability of dopamine (DA), a neurotransmitter involved in reward and addiction. Here, we show that the brain DA response to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular DA, is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also show higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the reduced brain DA response to MP in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors and negative emotionality.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s processing of language is a central focus of neuroscience. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural network models for language processing also predict the brain’s responses to language in humans. This suggests that the brain’s language processing is fundamentally computational, and that the models’ internal representations capture the essence of language processing. These results provide computational evidence for the brain’s predictive processing of language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. This paper shows that the instability is not due to the underlying mathematics, but rather due to the lack of theoretical understanding of the relationship between stability and the ability to compute a neural network. We develop a theory of stability and approximation for neural networks, and use it to prove that the instability is inherent in the problem. This theory is then used to prove that there are problems where it is impossible to compute a stable neural network, even with infinite time and memory. This is a significant advance in our understanding of the limits of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major challenge for science and society. It is also a major challenge for science communication. In this paper, we discuss the importance of critically evaluating scientific research, especially when it is presented to the public. We do so by discussing a classic psychological experiment, which has been cited in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. We show that the experiment’s critical design flaws were not recognized at the time of its publication, and we discuss the implications of this for the study of human behavior.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae, has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and the disease is associated with the loss of several functions. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a new species of leprosy bacillus, M. lepromatosis, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to cause disease in the nervous system, and that the two species are remarkably similar in terms of their genome content and evolution. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of the leprosy disease and for the development of new therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also fundamental to thermodynamics, which is the study of the macroscopic properties of isolated systems. However, the study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy in isolated systems is a very challenging task. This is because the system is in a pure state, which makes the evolution unitary, and it is isolated, which makes the evolution nonlocal. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The development of a vaccine against COVID-19 is a global priority. Here, we report the development of a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, using a simple and fast approach. The vaccine is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated virus, which is easy to manufacture and can be stored at 4 °C. The vaccine is highly protective in hamsters, and the protective effect is maintained for at least 12 months. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs.

Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector, which is a major vector of plague today. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research on animal cognition. However, to understand the evolution of brain power, we need to look at the number of neurons, which is the brain’s basic computational unit. This study shows that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. This study provides a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying ADF/cofilin’s action are not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin is able to sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells. We propose a mechanochemical model that explains our experimental observations. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in cells and for the development of new strategies to control the activity of this important protein.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food, leading to a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. The results also suggest that the brain may be a target for the development of interventions to reduce the risk of obesity and its comorbidities. This study also provides evidence that the brain is a target for the development of interventions to reduce the risk of obesity and its comorbidities.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the island’s isolation. This work suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not in the same room, and that in-person interaction is not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are modified in a variety of ways that can have profound effects on protein synthesis. In this study, we show that the most common modification in coding regions, pseudouridine (Ψ), can alter the rate of translation. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can have subtle effects on the translation of mRNAs. This study provides insight into the role of mRNA modifications in protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and the feeling that life is worthwhile is associated with positive change over time. These findings suggest that the feeling that life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging.

Aquatic mammals are larger than their terrestrial relatives, but the extent to which potential ecological, biomechanical, and physiological controls contributed to this pattern remains untested quantitatively. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the leading cause of the common cold, and the development of rhinovirus vaccines is a major goal in the field of vaccine development. However, the mechanisms that determine the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication are not well understood. Here, we show that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We also show that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus induces a more efficient antiviral defense response at 37 °C than at 33 °C, which correlates with higher levels of type I and type III IFNs and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication and may help to guide the development of rhinovirus vaccines. (PsycINFO Database Record

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in humans and animals. It is also one of the most important opportunistic pathogens that cause chronic infections in patients with compromised immune systems. The ability of this bacterium to cause disease is due to its ability to adapt to its environment and to produce a wide range of virulence factors. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili as a sensor to detect the mechanical activity of the surface on which it is growing. This results in a positive feedback loop that promotes the long-term attachment of the bacterium to the surface, thereby facilitating the production of additional virulence factors. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria sense the mechanical activity of their environment and how this information is used to regulate virulence. It also provides a new target for the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased even more. However, the impact of these changes on the quality of surface water is unknown. We show that the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased the risk of exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels for surface water and sediments. This is a substantial risk to the biological integrity of global water resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the long-term persistence of the virus in animal reservoirs is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the identification of multiple lineages of the virus in deer and humans. Our findings suggest that deer are a potential source of human infection, and highlight the need for a comprehensive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. These discoveries have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our results have implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is associated with the presence of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. However, the earliest stages of AD are characterized by a plaque-independent inflammatory response, which is not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) secreted by neurons are potent inducers of a plaque-independent microgliosis. This neuron-derived inflammatory response is associated with the vulnerability of the brain regions and may precede the formation of Aβ plaques. Thus, we propose that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may be a key factor in the development of AD. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in human history. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation remains elusive. We show that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest known site where economic exploitation of chickens was practiced on a large scale. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. Our results are supported further by an extensive survey of the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a key process in biology, but it is difficult to study because of the slow kinetics. Here, we show that the folding of the large maltose binding protein can be studied by a combination of techniques that allows the study of the kinetics of the folding process at high structural resolution. The results show that the folding of the protein is composed of two steps. The first step is fast and involves the formation of a native-like intermediate. The second step is slow and involves the formation of the native state. The results have implications for the design of proteins with improved folding properties. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing these caps, RppH, has a unique substrate specificity for Np4-capped RNAs, which we have elucidated. This specificity is due to the unusual manner in which the δ-phosphate of Np4 is recognized by the active site of RppH, resulting in the generation of a monophosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which bacteria can reprogram gene expression in response to stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanism of action is the production of cytokines that cause tissue damage and organ failure. We hypothesized that arginine, a key amino acid in the immune system, could be used to treat sepsis. We found that arginine administration was more efficient than citrulline in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing sepsis-induced Treg and MDSC expansion. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of all living organisms is a fundamental quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of all living organisms and their distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a key input for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time in a self-organized way, without being externally driven, and the system’s activity is proportional to its current state. The mathematical description of SOC is still an active area of research. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a material with a high sensitivity to external factors, such as pressure, temperature, and electric and magnetic fields. These properties make diamond a promising material for a wide range of applications, including energy storage, sensing, and quantum technologies. However, the properties of diamond can be modified by external factors, such as strain. In this work, we show that diamond can be completely metallized, without phonon instability, by applying strain below a threshold level. This work opens up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond by strain engineering. This work also provides a framework for understanding the relationship between strain and the properties of diamond. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the development of diamond-based technologies.

The study of plant immunity has been dominated by the study of the immune system of the plant itself. However, the immune system of the pathogen is also important, and the study of the fungal immune system is just beginning. In this work, we show that a plant antifungal peptide has antifungal activity against plant fungal pathogens. This work provides a starting point for the study of the antifungal immune system of plant pathogens.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between sperm and the female reproductive tract (FRT). However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the FRT. We also show that female-derived proteins become more abundant in sperm after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, where it promotes blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and that the binding is regulated by flow. We also show that force application switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, which explains the pathophysiology of VWD. This work provides a mechanism for the regulation of VWF binding to platelets, which is important for understanding the effects of mutations in VWD. It also provides a method for measuring the effects of force on biological systems. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microorganisms that is intimately linked to human health. The human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on humans, is a major component of the microbiome, but it has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which will enable the study of the virome in a wide range of human diseases.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability to measure the aerosol–cloud interaction processes. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This instrument is used to investigate the aerosol–cloud interaction processes. The results show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path, but does increase the number of cloud droplets and decrease the droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the early Earth was a subject of intense debate for decades, with estimates ranging from 400 °C to 0 °C. The temperature of the surface today is determined by the balance between solar radiation and heat loss to space. This study provides a new method for determining the temperature of the early Earth, based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. The results suggest that the temperature of the early Earth decreased over time. This is consistent with other methods of determining the temperature of the early Earth, and provides a new perspective on the evolution of life on Earth.

Ion channels are the main ion-conductive proteins in cells and are responsible for the regulation of ion flow. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the control of cell excitability and the regulation of ion homeostasis. The K+ channel, the BK channel, is a large-conductance, voltage-gated potassium channel that is involved in a variety of physiological processes. The BK channel is unique in that it does not have an intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation and inactivation are state-dependent and that its C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent. These findings provide insights into the regulation of ion channels and the control of ion homeostasis. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The malaria parasite is able to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. The invasion process is a complex event, and the role of the red blood cell in the process has been largely ignored. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the RBC, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of new antimalarial strategies. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a material with a high sensitivity to external factors, such as pressure, temperature, and light. These properties make diamond a promising material for a wide range of applications, including energy storage, sensing, and optoelectronics. However, diamond is also a material with a high sensitivity to external factors, such as pressure, temperature, and light. These properties make diamond a promising material for a wide range of applications, including energy storage, sensing, and optoelectronics. In this work, we explore the possibility of metallization of diamond, which would allow diamond to be used in applications where it is currently not suitable. We show that metallization of diamond is possible, and we provide a detailed understanding of the mechanisms involved. Our work opens up new opportunities for the development of diamond-based devices and materials.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza virus infection. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in caspase-1/11, an enzyme involved in the innate immune response to influenza virus infection. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome during influenza virus infection. They also suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus transmission and disease severity. These findings may help to develop strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection. (PsycINFO Database Record

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of a sentence is organized in a way that is consistent with the merge operation proposed by linguists. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up or left-corner parser to build a hierarchy of phrases from the incoming language stream. This is the first time that the brain’s activity during the construction of a sentence has been recorded in humans.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are functionally redundant, but they are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the canonical Wnt pathway. We believe that this study will help to understand the function of redundant genes in the context of tissue-specific regulation.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. In this study, we show that stimulation of LH neurons that project to the lateral part of the LH (LH GABA) promotes eating in sated animals. We also show that this system is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, but rather is involved in the promotion of overeating.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in agricultural systems is a major driver of the global food supply. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would allow for the delivery of nitrogen in a more sustainable manner. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its future is uncertain. We study a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation and improve forest management. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sounds, which is essential for survival. The auditory organs of animals are all part of the body, and the size of the body is constrained by the environment and the energy budget of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, and the hearing is extended to the web, which is not part of the body. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave. The spider can also supersize the web to increase the surface area of the acoustic sensor. This study provides insights into the outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders and provides a unique model for studying extended and regenerative sensing. It also provides a new perspective for the design of acoustic flow detectors. (Show more)

Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges of our time. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. Vaccines are the most effective way to end the pandemic, but the current vaccines are not available to all the world’s population. This study reports a recombinant protein vaccine candidate that can be produced at a large scale, is highly immunogenic, and can be used to develop a vaccine against variants of concern. This vaccine candidate can be used to develop a vaccine for COVID-19 in the future.

The role of the ALK receptor in development is well established. However, the ligand(s) for human ALK are still unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like proteins (DrALKals) are ligands for human ALK. We further show that the DrALKals are involved in the development of iridophores, a pigment cell type of neural crest origin. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK-like proteins in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study provides a link between ALK-like proteins and neural crest development and opens up the possibility to study the role of ALK-like proteins in human diseases.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex story that has been told through archaeological, historical, and paleopathological evidence. Here, we present the genomes of 17 Yersinia pestis strains from the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical period in the development of the disease. Our results show that the emergence of plague was a gradual process, with a single lineage evolving over thousands of years. We also discover the presence of a flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which was previously only found in the Caucasus and the Volga regions. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, which will be useful for understanding the spread of the disease throughout human history. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. (PsycINFO Database Record

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols has released massive amounts of SOC to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can sequester SOC on these soils. These practices also enhance the microbial properties that are critical for SOC stabilization. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC on a global scale and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors associated with spillover of viruses from animals to humans, and used this to rank the risk of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from 509,721 samples from 74,635 animals, and demonstrated the utility of the framework by using it to prioritize the investigation of 12 viruses with the highest spillover potential. The SpillOver platform is a living database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators to flowers. However, the color of nectar is not a simple trait, as it is often derived from a variety of compounds. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait in two other plant species, Jaltomata herrerae and Nesocodon, that are visited by hummingbirds. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a simple trait that is likely to be found in many plant species. This is important because it suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 480 and 700 AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestries of women are very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we find that women with artificial skull deformations had ancestries that were very different from those of other women. These findings suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Middle Ages may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly emerged pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. These findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and its potential to cause future pandemics. This article is protected by copyright

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and control of epidemics. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our findings highlight the potential of mNGS to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in lagging strand replication. It also provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in lagging strand replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and most difficult problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA from an RNA template. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life, as it allows the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 are summarized. The results show that the immune system of patients with severe COVID-19 is in a state of imbalance, and the immune response is overactive. Tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can effectively reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also highly toxic at high concentrations. The existence of a fungal copper-binding analog of the widely distributed bacterial siderophore, the siderophore xanthocillin, is surprising, as no fungal analogs of other metal-binding siderophores have been described. This study demonstrates that the xan BGC-derived isocyanide product of Aspergillus fumigatus is a copper-binding molecule, and that this molecule has significant antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study also demonstrates the utility of a simple, inexpensive, and sensitive assay for the detection of copper-binding molecules. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, which is not stable at the temperatures of the present-day Martian surface. Tridymite is a common mineral in the interiors of silicic volcanoes, and the presence of such a mineral in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit on Mars is a significant discovery.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere, but the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly associated with the leaf-out strategies of trees, with species that are more likely to experience frost in spring having later-leafing strategies. We also show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is already affecting the performance of trees. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether these cells are required for disease or are merely a bystander. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells. These cells are dependent on the transcription factor T-bet, which is required for the development of both Th17 and Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Furthermore, our results indicate that the development of Th1 cells can be influenced by Th17 cells. This suggests that the balance between these two subsets of cells may be important for the development of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which control muscle movement. The disease is caused by mutations in several genes, but the cause of the disease in most patients is unknown. We report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living patients into induced astrocytes, which are the cells that cause the disease. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that can prevent the disease. This will help in the development of new treatments for ALS. This method can be used to study other neurodegenerative diseases as well. This method will also help in the development of treatments for other diseases caused by astrocytes, such as stroke and epilepsy.

The gut microbiota of ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the gut microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma to vertebrate hosts. We demonstrate that the ability of antifreeze glycoprotein to alter the composition of the gut microbiota is due to its ability to bind the d-alanine terminus of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitate transmission to vertebrate hosts. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is a key transition in the origin of modern birds. The study of the early evolution of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian body plan. Here, we report the discovery of a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases our understanding of the early evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the modern avian body plan.

We show that the stratospheric water vapor feedback is a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity of the climate system. This is a surprising result, because the stratosphere is a region of strong climate variability, and it is not obvious that the climate system should be able to respond to this variability. We show that the climate system is able to respond to the stratospheric water vapor feedback, and that the response is consistent with the observed feedback.

Chlorosis is a phenomenon in which vertebrates have unusually high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood. This study shows that the presence of biliverdin-binding serpins (BBSs) is a key factor in the evolution of chlorosis, and that BBSs are a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. These findings also provide a molecular basis for the evolution of green coloration in vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a key feature of the tumor microenvironment, and is associated with increased breast cancer incidence and mortality. However, the mechanisms that regulate the development of breast cancer in hypoxic conditions are not well understood. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is dependent on ALKBH5 and HIF-1α and HIF-2α, and is associated with the development of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, our findings suggest that hypoxia induces ALKBH5 expression, which in turn increases NANOG expression, and that this pathway may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was a major innovation, and the source of this parchment has been a long-standing mystery. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface, followed by analysis of the extracted proteins by mass spectrometry. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. This method provides a simple and objective way to identify the animal origin of parchment, and could be used to study the use of animal hides in the production of other ancient books.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age model shows that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. This work will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. It will also establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, such as metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium has not been well studied. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also show that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides insights into the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium and its potential as a therapeutic target for IBD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target of the immune system and of vaccines. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in the open conformation, which is associated with higher infectivity. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. Our results provide insights into the mechanism of infectivity and may help to design vaccines and treatments. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
