COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic will result in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are fundamental to chemistry, and they are also the basis of the chemical reactivity of molecules. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is a general trend for most elements. We also show that the chemical properties of the elements change dramatically under pressure, and we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show that our results are consistent with the chemical rules of the periodic table, and we show that our results are also predictive of the chemical behavior of elements under pressure. Our results are of fundamental importance to chemistry, and they are also of great interest for the study of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, which can have important consequences for the global carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are highly uncertain, and the role of human ignitions is not well understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce fire activity, which can have important consequences for the global carbon cycle. Our results suggest that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to better understand the role of human ignitions in future fire regimes.

The provision of nutrients to microbial communities associated with epithelial surfaces is a widespread strategy used by animals to control the composition of their microbiota. However, the mechanisms by which this control is exerted are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to control the persistence of a luminescent symbiont in a specific niche of the host. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis, and that this catabolism is restricted to a specific time of the day. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients at specific times of the day may be a general strategy used by animals to control the composition of their microbiota. This control may be exerted by the catabolism of specific glycans, which in turn modulates the conditions in the habitat of the symbionts.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a generative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives of violent deaths (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression). We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, and it can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to identify latent patterns in text data from many domains.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the mid-14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe, after which it spread over the continent. We show that this assumption is not supported by our analysis of climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague outbreaks. We find that the introduction of the plague into Europe was preceded by a reintroduction of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia. Our results suggest that the plague bacterium was not permanently established in Europe, but was reintroduced into Europe on multiple occasions. This finding challenges the traditional view of the second plague pandemic and its causes. (Less)

Asteroids are a group of marine invertebrates that are of great interest to science and industry. They are also a major component of the marine ecosystem. In the last 2 y, a disease has been observed in populations of asteroids on the Pacific coast of North America. This disease is characterized by rapid death, loss of turgor, and loss of limbs. We show that the disease is caused by a virus. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis is poor. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in treating AML in mice. We also show that the antibodies are effective in treating primary human AML cells. These results provide evidence that IL1RAP can be targeted with antibodies that can achieve antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and block IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Thus, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an antibody capable of achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. This approach may be useful for treating AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar. It will help to understand the origin of the Malagasy population and the settlement history of Madagascar. It will also help to understand the genetic diversity of the Indian Ocean islands. Finally, it will help to understand the origin of the human populations in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in the United States. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be easily adapted to other countries and crops.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that these changes can be used to store information in a dynamic memory register. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is a key uncertainty in our understanding of future global warming. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most studied, but the molecular mechanisms underlying this transition are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is accompanied by a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. We propose a model of the evolutionary trajectory of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is characterized by the loss of photosynthesis and the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle. Our findings have implications for the evolution of plastid genomes in general and for the evolution of the parasitic lifestyle in particular. They also provide a framework for the study of the molecular evolution of the plastid genome in the context of environmental change.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a first step towards quantifying the impact of climate change on the water security of cities. However, more research is needed to improve the representation of the complex processes that control the occurrence of droughts. This will allow for a more robust assessment of the impact of climate change on water security.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, which was formed in the seconds after the explosion, is significant because it demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed under conditions that are not associated with the extreme pressures and temperatures that are required for the formation of naturally occurring quasicrystals. This discovery has implications for the search for new quasicrystal-forming systems. (Show more)

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. The oxygenic photosynthetic organisms are cyanobacteria and plants, and both use the same core machinery for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The biosynthesis of the chlorophyll pigments is a highly productive biological pathway, and the isocyclic fifth ring of the chlorophyll molecule is formed by two unrelated enzymes. This work shows that the two enzymes are part of a larger protein complex, and that the evolution of the isocyclic ring is linked to the evolution of oxygenic photosynthesis.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known that neuroinflammation is associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of disease. These findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the roles of glial cells in the pathogenesis of EAE. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. We also show that the probability of drought has increased if precipitation deficits occur when conditions are warm. These findings are important for understanding the causes of the current drought and for planning for the future.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which was indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of autism and may facilitate the development of treatments. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in the channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 and the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 are associated with severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that cause a Stormorken-like syndrome of bleeding diathesis and miosis, and a Stormorken syndrome of bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. These findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that this spreading is associated with the internalization of aggregates. We also show that the release of aggregates requires the fusion protein 1 complex, which is important for the active release of aggregates from the cell surface. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein has the potential to inhibit the host immune system and facilitate viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this protein. These findings may help to prevent the emergence of new viral diseases in humans and animals. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus the study of cancer metabolism is a major focus of cancer research. In this study, we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and develop a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon unit biosynthetic enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase. We show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cells, and that it is particularly effective in cancer cells of the B-cell lineage. We also show that cancer cells have unique metabolic vulnerabilities, and that these vulnerabilities can be exploited to develop more effective therapies. Thus, the study of cancer metabolism is a major focus of cancer research, and the development of effective therapies will require the development of effective therapies that exploit cancer’s metabolic vulnerabilities.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a number of genes, including those that encode for proteins that are involved in the metabolism of iron, copper, and zinc. These proteins are highly aggregation-prone and form intracellular inclusions that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions are populated by proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, but become supersaturated upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to be broadly applicable to the study of many-body physics with neutral atoms. The 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is a major event in the evolution of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic and some have suggested that they originated in a dark forest habitat. This study presents a detailed analysis of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the early Cretaceous. The results show that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, a group that includes the water lilies. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. This study raises questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade and the role of aquatic habitats in the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral DNA in the archaeological record. Here we present the first ancient human viruses, which were recovered from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is a key indicator of climate change because it is sensitive to both global warming and to oceanic and atmospheric variability. We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with climate change. This result is robust to the choice of satellite altimetry data, averaging method, and sea level definition.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a pressing need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the development of remdesivir for clinical trials, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to microbial communities associated with epithelial surfaces is a widespread strategy used by animals to control the composition of their microbiota. However, the mechanisms by which this control is exerted are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to control the persistence of a luminescent symbiont in a specific niche of the host. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis, and that this catabolism is restricted to the night, when the host is active and the symbionts are producing light. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients at specific times of the day may be a general strategy used by animals to control the activities of their associated microbiota.

DNA alkylation is one of the major sources of DNA damage in living cells. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of the spike (S) glycoprotein. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems. The food choices people make are a key driver of these problems. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40%. This is equivalent to a proportional increase of 61% in the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased. The study also shows that this increase in vegetarian meals is sustained over time and does not lead to a rebound effect. These findings have implications for the food system, public health, and the environment. They suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could have a significant impact on the environment and population health. This study provides evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to analyze the surface proteome of cells, and applied it to characterize the surfaceome of a panel of oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a unique surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the molecular basis of the disease. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is unique in its ability to form a covalent disulfide-linked dimer. This structure provides insight into the molecular basis of the unique properties of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, including its ability to evade the immune system. This structure will be useful for the development of new therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), its receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the up-regulated expression of CRFR1 and AQP4 in hypoxic rats contributes to the development of edema via the up-regulation of ET-1 expression in cortical astrocytes. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying hypoxic cerebral edema and suggest that CRFR1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of this condition. The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It addresses the question of how to properly assess the strength of associations that we find in a data set. This is a difficult problem, because we have “cherry-picked” the data set (the “cherry tree”) by searching for the strongest associations. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. These developments are important because they allow us to make more efficient use of the data that we have, and to make more powerful inferences.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a key factor for the direct conversion of fibroblasts into ECs. ETV2 is essential for the development of ECs, and its expression is required for the formation of mature vascular networks in vivo. These findings provide a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This approach could be applied to the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important for the development of the eye and the skin. Here, we show that the two ligands of these RTKs, ALKAL1 and ALKAL2, are essential for the development of the eye and the skin in zebrafish. We also show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized skin tissue that is responsible for the coloration of the fish. These findings establish a physiological link between the ligands and the RTKs and demonstrate that the ligands are important for the development of iridophores. This work provides insights into the function of these two RTKs and their ligands. It also provides a model system for the study of the function of other orphan RTKs.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem, and the molecular mechanisms underlying its development are still poorly understood. In this study, we found that the STING gene is expressed in β-cells and plays a critical role in the regulation of insulin secretion. We also found that STING deficiency in β-cells causes a loss of β-cell function, which is associated with the down-regulation of Pax6. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying T2D and suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of this disease. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are composed of eight segments of single-stranded RNA, which are packaged into the virion. The packaging of the viral genome is a highly conserved process, but the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which is required for the selective packaging of the viral genome. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (PsycINFO Database Record

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a major threat to human life and property, as well as a major cause of ecosystem degradation. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity. However, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the need for policies to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

Urban change is a complex process that is difficult to observe and understand. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insects. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods are largely unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions. This study provides insights into the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help in the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of ZIKV is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model, which allows for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the model is able to reproduce the observed within-host dynamics of ZIKV, and we use the model to assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to clearance of ZIKV. Our results suggest that the treatment should be given prophylactically starting at the time of infection, and that favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, is a promising candidate for the treatment of ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In particular, the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis caused by heat stress is a major cause of mass mortality events. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This process is a key factor in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis and may help explain the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn activate a JNK-mediated feedback loop that drives the dysregulation of the microbiome and the development of intestinal barrier dysfunction. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function and the host–microbe homeostasis, leading to a lifespan extension. Our work identifies a mechanism that links intestinal tumors to the microbiome and highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing strategies to control tumorigenesis. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response of patients to this treatment is highly variable. We show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this up-regulation is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. We also show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can repress the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impair the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is marked by a rapid warming of the climate, with many theories for the cause. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which, in turn, caused a rapid warming of the Southern Hemisphere. This is the first time that a volcanic eruption has been linked to deglaciation, and it is a significant advance in our understanding of the causes of deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people, but they are often overlooked in global assessments. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and the sustainability of fisheries. We find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis also reveals that fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian brain. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery opens up a new platform for the discovery of factors that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of all living organisms. In this study, we use a population of wild plants to map the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant. We find that the distribution of recombination events is highly structured, with some regions of the genome that are highly active, interspersed with regions that are inactive or even silent. These results provide a detailed view of the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant, and may be relevant to the evolution of recombination in plants and animals.

The resting brain is assumed to be organized into functional networks, each of which is associated with a specific function. However, the existence of such networks is still debated. Here, we show that the dominant resting metabolic network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the DMN, but that this network is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. This finding has implications for the interpretation of functional MRI studies, and for the development of new therapies for neurodegenerative diseases.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is a well-known feature of eukaryotic mRNA. However, the existence of other 5′ modifications in eukaryotes has been debated. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ modification in yeast, which we call nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA. We show that NAD+ RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We also show that NAD+ RNA is produced cotranscriptionally, and that it is not modified after transcription. These results define an additional 5′ modification in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This work also provides a model for the evolution of 5′ modifications in eukaryotes. (Show more)

The study of epigenetic mechanisms has led to the discovery of DNA methylation as a key factor in the regulation of gene expression. In this study, we show that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood cells is associated with glycemia, and that these DNA-methylation patterns persist over time in people with diabetes. These results support the hypothesis that epigenetic mechanisms are involved in the metabolic memory phenomenon. This study also provides a better understanding of the mechanisms involved in the development of diabetes complications.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and there is a need for the identification of new therapeutic targets. We show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells promotes autophagy, inhibits mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin signaling, and enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling. These findings suggest that FSIP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for TNBC treatment. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit is essential for the development of a distinctive aroma, but the biosynthetic pathways of these compounds are unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the final products. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of these compounds and will be of interest to researchers in the field of plant metabolism.

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This is a critical finding for understanding the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to represent different aspects of space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to represent the local environment, are organized in a distinct manner from other cell types. These data provide a more complete picture of the organization of MEC neurons and will be useful for understanding the function of this important brain region. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for the flowering of the host and the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra project to the striatum in a classic manner, but that they also form specialized integrative units within the nigral system. These units, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are formed by striosomes, dopamine-containing dendrites, and other nigral cells. The striosome–dendron bouquets are likely critical to the processing of dopamine-related information in the brain.

We all know when we’re “clicking” with someone, but how do we know when two people are “clicking” with each other? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly coordinated system, and the precise timing of the electrical impulse is critical for the heart to beat at the proper rate. This study shows that the calcium store of the SAN cells is important for the proper timing of the electrical impulse. This work provides insight into the mechanisms that control the timing of the electrical impulse in the heart. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants enhanced resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect was associated with an increase in the accumulation of Si and the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si and JA interact in the defense response against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest control. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the ability to store and integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall in plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiencies. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

Nutrient inputs from small tributaries are a major source of eutrophication in large freshwater systems. However, most studies have focused on large watersheds, and the role of small tributaries has been largely overlooked. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of nutrients to the nearshore zone of large lakes. We found that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan accounted for 70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries were responsible for 80% of the daily nutrient loads that were dissolved inorganic and available for uptake by algae. This finding suggests that small tributaries may be a major source of coastal algal blooms. Our results highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication and provide a framework for understanding the relative importance of different watershed sizes in driving coastal nutrient inputs. This information is critical for developing effective nutrient management strategies to protect coastal ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems theory. We also find that the dynamics of the system are sensitive to the details of the environment, and that the system can exhibit a variety of different behaviors depending on the details of the environment. These results have implications for understanding the dynamics of complex systems in a variety of contexts.

The role of the brain’s electrical activity in the development of clinical symptoms is a major focus of neuroscience research. Here, we show that the presence of a high-affinity antibody against a specific type of glutamate receptor can change the electrical properties of the brain, leading to changes in the brain’s spontaneous activity and susceptibility to paroxysmal events. These findings offer insights into the mechanisms underlying the clinical symptoms of autoimmune encephalitis. They also suggest that the electrical activity of the brain may be a useful biomarker for the presence of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. This work may also have implications for the development of new therapies for this disease.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of our understanding of the Earth system. However, the history of the C cycle during abrupt climate change is poorly understood. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate a major C perturbation during a glacial period. We show that the perturbation was associated with a global warming event, which was accompanied by an increase in atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and an increase in the thermocline, which in turn led to an increase in organic matter burial. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of abrupt climate change and the role of the C cycle in these events. (Show more)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification scheme for palm oil, a major driver of deforestation in tropical forests. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia by 33%. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. However, the molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex in regulating the final steps of exocytosis is not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a small molecule, Endosidin2, which inhibits the exocytosis of plant cells and human cells. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and its role in human disease. It also offers a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental trait in the evolution of vertebrates, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species with four possible sex classes. We find that the interplay of sex determination alleles produces modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the acquisition of a new sex determination allele can create additional axes of variation for secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide context for understanding the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. They also suggest that the maintenance of sex determination alleles may be more complex than previously thought.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the presence of iron is known to promote oxidative damage. However, the retina is also a tissue that is rich in iron, and the role of iron in the retina is not well understood. Here, we show that the presence of iron in the retina is important for the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E. This work provides insight into the role of iron in the retina and the importance of iron in the regulation of the redox state of the retina. These findings also have implications for the development of strategies to protect the retina from oxidative damage. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the key to understanding how ecosystems function, but the evolution of their feeding strategies is poorly understood. We show that the evolution of siphonophore tentilla, the structures used for prey capture, is linked to the evolution of prey type. Our results show that siphonophore specialists can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have directly evolved into specialists on other prey types. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of Acheulian technology. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the one-carbon unit derived from the metabolism of serine. We report the discovery of a series of small-molecule inhibitors of serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for colon cancer, but uniquely lethal to a panel of B-cell cancers. We also show that one-carbon unit deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, the discovery of SHMT inhibitors has the potential to improve the therapeutic options for patients with colon cancer and B-cell cancers. This work is a step toward the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamin A, and thus their vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which can improve their vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets as well as their conservation and environmental benefits. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a relatively new area of research, and we hope that this study will encourage more research in this area.

The mechanization of agriculture has been a key factor in the success of modern civilization. However, the increase in the weight of farm machinery has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, with potential loss of productivity. We show that the total area of subsoil compaction risk has increased from 10% of arable land in the 1960s to 20% today, with the risk of subsoil compaction being now present in 10% of the world’s arable land. We hypothesize that the development of subsoil compaction has been driven by the increase in the weight of farm machinery, and that this trend will continue to increase in the future.
